title: Subcellular fractionation of suspension Chinese Hamster Ovary (CHO) cells

source.description: Quantify cell concentration and viability during cell culture to reach 300-700 millions of viable cells, with a viability higher than 90%.

Centrifuge cells at
, in
conical tubes.
Discard supernatant gently to avoid any cell lost.

Resuspend cellular pellet to about 3-7 x 107 cells/ml in
of cold phosphate buffer (
NaCl,
KCl,
Na2HPO4,
KH2PO4).

source.body: Calculate total viable cells present in the pellet by multiplying collected culture volume and viable cell concentration. Pool as many cell pellets as necessary to complete the total number of viable cells required for the procedure.

source.description:
Centrifuge cells at
, in
conical tubes.
Discard supernatant gently.

Resuspend cell pellet in
of cold phosphate buffer.
Repeat steps 5 and 6 once.

Resuspend cell pellet in
of hypotonic buffer (
HEPES,
EDTA,

Incubate the cell suspension during
, inverting tube every
.

Add PMSF to a final concentration of
and
of prepared
Protease Inhibitor Tablets to every 350 millions of cells.

source.body: To prepare Protease Inhibitor Tablets, dissolve one tablet in of sterile MilliQ water, filter through a 0.2 µm filter and distribute aliquots in 1-2 ml eppendorf tubes. Keep at until use.

source.description:
Transfer the cells to a Dounce homogenizer, and disrupt them by 25 strokes,
.

source.body: Since cell disruption must be optimized for each cell line in order to reach maximum efficiency and organelle integrity, number of strokes should be carefully evaluated in a case by case basis.

Another cell disruption method, such as nitrogen cavitation
, sonication
and Balch homogenizer
⁠, can be evaluated, depending on availability.

source.description:
Restore isotonicity immediately by adding
of 45% (w/v) sucrose solution, prepared in the hypotonic buffer, to the cell homogenate.

Transfer disrupted cells back again to
tubes and homogenize this suspension by inversion.

Distribute the cell homogenate in
aliquots into
microcentrifuge tubes.

Centrifuge at
.

Collect supernatant and distribute it to new
microcentrifuge tubes. Tag the pellet as Nuclear Fraction and maintain it
.

Centrifuge the collected supernatant at
.

Collect and pool the new supernatant in
, Open-Top Thinwall Ultra-Clear/Polypropylene Tube, 14 x 89 mm. Tag the pellet as Mitochondrial Fraction and maintain it
.

Centrifuge the pooled supernatant at
, in a SW40Ti rotor, using an Optima XE-90 Ultracentrifuge.

source.body: Any other ultracentrifuge compatible with this rotor and running settings can be used.

Read all product manuals and consult with Beckman Coulter-trained personnel before attempting to operate the instrument. Do not attempt to perform any procedure before carefully reading all instructions. Always follow product labeling and manufacturer’s recommendations. If in doubt as to how to proceed in any situation, contact your Beckman Coulter Representative.

source.description:
Collect the supernatant in
conical tubes. Tag the pellet as Microsomal Fraction, and supernatant as Cytosol, and maintain both
.

Precipitate proteins from supernatant (cytosol) immediately, as detailed below, and storage protein pellet at
until use.

source.body: If the proteomic analysis will make use of the differential fractionation samples, without any further separations, storage nuclear, mitochondrial and microsomal pellets at until use. In case that these pellets will be separated in density gradients, do not freeze these samples, and proceed to separation immediately after their obtaining.

source.description:
Prepare discontinuous sucrose gradients
by depositing the indicated volumes on the tube wall, drop by drop, slowly.

source.body:
Use a gradient of of 60% (w/v) and of each solution of 55, 40 and 30% (w/v) sucrose, placed from the bottom to the top of the tube, for separation of nuclear and mitochondrial pellets
⁠.
A second one formed by 60% (w/v) and of each solution of 45, 35, 30 and 10% (w/v) sucrose, placed from the bottom to the top of the tube, will be used for separation of microsomal pellet.
Sucrose solutions should always be deposited in decreasing order of concentration. The interface between these solutions should always be visible, except in the case of 30/35% where it is difficult to distinguish. Discard gradients if interfaces are not clearly visible. Use , Open-Top Thinwall Ultra-Clear/Polypropylene Tube, 14 x 89 mm to prepare gradients. All solutions should be kept on ice throughout the procedure, and prepared according to the percentage of sucrose indicated in each case (w/v), in a buffer with a final composition of HEPES and EDTA, .

source.description:
Pool all the mitochondrial pellets by resuspending them gently in
of isotonic buffer [
sucrose (w/v),
HEPES,
EDTA,
].

Divide nuclear pellets in 4 groups, and pool each group by resuspending them gently in
of isotonic buffer.

Resuspend the microsomal pellet in
of isotonic buffer.

Add each resuspended pellet to the top of the corresponding sucrose gradient and centrifuge at
(max), in a SW40Ti rotor, using an Optima XE-90 Ultracentrifuge, with maximal and medium acceleration and deceleration rates, respectively.

source.body: Any other ultracentrifuge compatible with this rotor and running settings can be used.

source.description:
Collect visible bands in each gradient by using a Pasteur pipette,
micropipette tips, a peristaltic pump, or by tube puncture or any other method suitable for fraction collection.

source.body: Three bands should be seen on each gradient, except for the nuclear gradient, where 4 bands are resolved.
The densest band on the nuclear gradient, located at the bottom of the tube, should be discarded as it represents cell debris.

source.description:
Precipitate proteins from each fraction collected from sucrose gradients by the protocol detailed below, and storage protein pellets at
until use.

Add
of
NaCl to
of sample in
conical tubes, and homogenize by vortex.

source.body:
This section has been optimized to precipitate complex protein mixtures from CHO cells
⁠. The obtained pellet can be shipped to a Proteomic Facility, at , for its processing and analysis. Total volumes should be changed according to available sample, always maintaining the indicated proportion of solutions.

source.description:
Add
of cold 80% (v/v) acetone and homogenize by vortex or inversions. Acetone should be kept at
, at least
before precipitation.

source.body: Acetone percentage can be increased to 100% (v/v) if protein recovery is not enough for proteomic analysis.
Use gloves, safety glasses and protective clothing. Do not eat, drink or smoke during use. Keep away from heat, hot surfaces, open flames, sparks. Keep container tightly closed.

source.description:

during
.

source.body: Incubation for a longer time could be necessary if protein recovery is not enough for proteomic analysis.

description:
Subcellular fractionation is a widely adopted technique to study cellular biology, and localization and functions of several proteins
⁠
, and, more recently, it has been applied previous to proteomics to quantify low concentration proteins, and characterize many subcellular organelles
⁠
. Since CHO cells play a central role for recombinant protein (RP) production, a deeper study of their cellular biology is mandatory in order to construct new cell sub-lines with a more robust RP expression phenotype. Therefore, the goal of the present protocol is to provide the necessary basis for separation of subcellular organelles from suspension Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells for a subsequent proteomic study of isolated fractions. Differential and isopycnic centrifugation based sections are presented for enrichment of different subcellular compartments, together with a precipitation section for recovering of proteins from isolated fractions. Isopycnic centrifugation is based on discontinuos sucrose gradients, of which one is adapted from the literature for the separation of nuclear and mitochondrial precipitates
, and the other is designed in our laboratory for the separation of the microsomal precipitate. This protocol provides a novel discontinuous sucrose gradient for the separation of the components of the microsomes, which increases the separation efficiency with respect to previously reported protocols
⁠.
